notes:
1. Concept

Dry friction (or Coulomb friction) is the force that resists the relative lateral motion between two solid surfaces in contact. The friction force, $f$, always acts parallel to the contacting surface and in a direction that opposes the motion or tendency of motion.

2. Static Friction ($f_s$)

Static friction acts when the surfaces are not moving relative to each other. The static friction force is a reactive force; it is only as large as it needs to be to prevent motion, up to a maximum value.

$$ f_s \le \mu_s N $$
  • $\mu_s$ is the coefficient of static friction (a dimensionless property of the two surfaces).
  • $N$ is the normal force perpendicular to the surface.

Motion is said to be impending when the friction force reaches its maximum possible value, $f_{s,max} = \mu_s N$.

3. Kinetic Friction ($f_k$)

Kinetic (or dynamic) friction acts when the surfaces are sliding relative to each other. The kinetic friction force has a constant magnitude as long as the surfaces are slipping.

$$ f_k = \mu_k N $$
  • $\mu_k$ is the coefficient of kinetic friction.

Typically, the coefficient of kinetic friction is less than the coefficient of static friction ($\mu_k < \mu_s$). This is why it takes more force to get an object moving than to keep it moving.

solvedExamples.question: A 10 kg block rests on a horizontal surface. The coefficient of static friction is $\mu_s = 0.5$. What is the maximum static friction force? (Use $g=9.8$ m/s²).
solvedExamples.explanation: First, find the normal force. Since the block is on a horizontal surface, the normal force equals the weight of the block: $N = W = mg = (10 \text{ kg})(9.8 \text{ m/s²}) = 98$ N. The maximum static friction force is $f_{s,max} = \mu_s N = (0.5)(98 \text{ N}) = 49$ N.

solvedExamples.question: A horizontal force of 30 N is applied to the 10 kg block from the previous problem ($f_{s,max} = 49$ N). What is the magnitude of the friction force acting on the block?
solvedExamples.explanation: The applied force (30 N) is less than the maximum possible static friction force (49 N). Therefore, the block will not move. The static friction force is a reactive force and will only be as large as necessary to prevent motion. In this case, it exactly balances the applied force, so $f_s = 30$ N.

solvedExamples.question: If the 10 kg block is sliding on a surface where the coefficient of kinetic friction is $\mu_k=0.3$, what is the kinetic friction force?
solvedExamples.explanation: The normal force is still $N = 98$ N. The kinetic friction force is constant while the object is sliding and is calculated as $f_k = \mu_k N = (0.3)(98 \text{ N}) = 29.4$ N.
